\label{gr1}
Let $G$ be a group and let $x,y,z$ be elements of $G$.


$(1)$  $e(xy) \leq \mbox{l.c.m.}(o(x),o(y))$.

$(2)$   If $o(x)=2$ and $y^a=y^{-1}$ for some $a \in $G, then $e(xy) \leq 4$.

$(3)$   If $o(x)=o(y)=o(z)=2$, then $e(xyz) \leq 4$.

nodes.proof:
(1). Let $g=xy$ and let $o(x)=n$, $o(y)=m$. Then 
$$h:= g \cdot g^x \cdot g^{x^2} \cdots g^{x^{m-1}} = x \cdot y^m \cdot x^{m-1} = x^m.$$ 
Writing $l = \mbox{l.c.m.}(n,m)=m \cdot s$, we obtain that $h^s = x^{ms} = x^l = 1$, therefore $e(g) \leq l$.

(2). Let $g=xy$. Then $g \cdot g^x \cdot g^a \cdot g^{xa} = 1$.

(3). Let $g=xyz$. Then
$g \cdot g^z \cdot g^x \cdot g^{zx} = 1$.

\label{xy8}
Denote by $e_G(g)$ the generalized order of $g$ in $G$. Let $x,y \in G$ be such that $xy=yx$. Let $m := e_{C_G(x)}(y)$, $n:=e_G(x^m)$. Then $e_G(xy) \leq n \cdot m$.
nodes.content_preview: Denote by e_G(g) the generalized order of g in G. Let x,y G be such that xy=yx. Let m := e_C_G(x)(y), n:=e_G(x^m). Then e_G(xy) n m.
nodes.label: xy8
nodes.proof:
We have $\prod_{i=1}^m y^{t_i} = 1$ with $t_i \in C_G(x)$ for all $i$. Then $\prod_{i=1}^m (xy)^{t_i} = \prod_{i=1}^m x \cdot y^{t_i} = x^m$. We have $\prod_{j=1}^n (x^m)^{r_j} = 1$ with $r_j \in G$ for all $j$. Therefore 
$$\prod_{j=1}^n \left( \prod_{i=1}^m (xy)^{t_ir_j} \right) = \prod_{j=1}^n \left( \prod_{i=1}^m (xy)^{t_i} \right)^{r_j} = \prod_{j=1}^n (x^m)^{r_j} = 1$$
hence $e_G(xy) \leq n \cdot m$.

nodes.proof:
We consider only the case of $G=\PSU_n(q)$, the other case is similar.

Let $H=\SU_n(q)=\SU(V)$    and let $h\in \U(V)$
be a matrix  permuting cyclically the elements of an orthonormal basis of $V$.
If $n$ is odd then $\det h=1$. If $n$ is even then $q$ is odd and $t:=\diag(-1,\Id_{n-1})\in \U(V)$ (under the same basis). Then $(th)^n=-\Id$ is scalar. Let $g\in G$ be the projection of 
$ h$. Then $|g|=n$. Note that  $h$ is regular in $H$ as $h$ has $n$ distinct eigenvalues, since $(n,q)=1$.
Therefore, $g$ is regular in $G$. By Lemma \ref{Gow}, $s$ is a product of two conjugates of $h$. By Lemma \ref{gr1}(1), $e(g)\leq n$.

nodes.proof:
Note that $(n+ 1,q)=1$. Let $x\in \U_{n+1}(q) = \U_{n+1}(V)$ be the matrix permuting cyclically an orthonormal basis of $V$. Then $x\in S_{n+1}$, the group of all permutations of the basis. 
Let $\mu=(-1)^{n}. $ As $(n+1,q)=1$, 
the multiplicity of the eigenvalue $\mu$ of $x$ equals 1. So the $\mu$-eigenspace $W$ of $x$ is non-degenerate, and hence $V=W^\perp\oplus W$. 

As $\det x=\mu$, we have $x=\diag(h,\mu)$,
where $h\in \SU_n(q)$. Since $h$ has $n$ distinct eigenvalues over $F$, $h$ is regular.
Let $g$ be the projection of $h$ in $G$. Then $|g|=n+1$.   
By Lemma \ref{Gow}, $s$ is a product of two conjugates of $g$. By Lemma \ref{gr1}, $e(s)\leq n+1$.

nodes.proof:
By Lemma \ref{Gow},  $g$ is not a regular semisimple element of $G$. 
Therefore, $C_G(g)$ contains a unipotent element $u\neq 1$, say, and we choose $u$ to be a generator of $ O_p(\langle g\rangle)$ whenever    
this group is non-trivial.

 Set $K= \langle g\rangle$. By a Borel-Tits theorem \cite[Theorem 26.5]{MTe}, 
$K$ is contained in a parabolic subgroup 
$P$, say, of $G$, and $O_p(K)\subseteq O_p(P)$. In particular, $u\in O_p(P)$.

For the additional claim, suppose the contrary, that $v\in U:=O_p(P)$ for some regular unipotent element $v$ of $G$.  If $L:=P/U$ contains no unipotent element then $P$ is a Borel subgroup of $G$ \cite[\S 26.1]{MTe}.  In this case $G$ is of BN-pair rank 1, and hence
 $G\in \{\PSL_2(q), \Sz(q) = {^2}B_2(q), {^2}G_2(q)\}$.
Otherwise,  the projection of $v$ into $P/U$ is non-trivial by \cite[Lemma 2.6]{tz13},
which is a contradiction.

\label{in3} Let $H=\GL_n(q)=\GL(V)$ and let $h=su\in H$ be indecomposable. 
Then $h$ is contained in a subgroup $M = M_1 M_2$, $[M_1,M_2] = 1$, $M_1 \cong \GL_k(q)$, $M_2 \cong \GL_l(q)$ for some integers $k,l$ with $kl=n$, and $s\in M_1,u\in M_2$. (In fact, $M=\GL_k(q)\otimes \GL_l(q)$, the Kronecker product.) In addition, $s$ is irreducible as an element of $\GL_k(q)$ and $u$ represents a Jordan block $J_l$ in $\GL_l(q)$.
nodes.content_preview: Let H=_n(q)=(V) and let h=su H be indecomposable. Then h is contained in a subgroup M = M_1 M_2, [M_1,M_2] = 1, M_1 _k(q), M_2 _l(q) for some...
nodes.label: in3
nodes.proof:
Let $V = \bigoplus_{i=1}^t V_i$, where $V_1,\ldots,V_t$ are homogeneous components of $s$ on $V$, i.e. each $V_i$ is the maximal direct sums of pairwise $\mathbb{F}_q \langle s \rangle$-isomorphic irreducible components. Then $uV_i=V_i$ for $i=1,\ldots, t$. As $h$ is indecomposable, we have $t=1$.
Therefore, $V$ is a direct sum of pairwise isomorphic irreducible ${\mathbb F}_q\langle s\rangle $-submodules of equal dimension $k$, say. It is well known (by Clifford theory and Schur's lemma) that $C_H(s)\cong \GL_l(q^k)$, where
$l$ is the composition length of $V$ and $k=n/l$. Then the conjugacy class of $u$  in $\GL_l(q^k)$ meets $\GL_l(q)$, since $u$ can be taken to its canonical Jordan form. We denote this group by $M_2$ and set $M_1=C_{\GL(V)}(M_2)$. We can view $M_1$ as the group $\diag(A,\ldots,  A)$ with $A \in \GL_k(q)$ and $M_2$ as $C_{\GL(V)}(M_1)$. A conjugate of $h$ lies in $M = M_1M_2$.

\label{i1i2i}
Let $g \in G$ be a semirational element of order $n$. Let 
$$\begin{array}{l}
I=\{m\ |\ 1 \leq m \leq n,\ (m,n)=1\}, \\
I_1=\{m \in I\ |\ g \sim g^m\}, \\
I_2=\{m \in I\ |\ g^{-1} \sim g^m\}.
\end{array}$$
We identify each integer with its reduction modulo $n$. Then $1 \in I_1$, $-1 \in I_2$ and $I_1 \cup I_2 = I$. If $h$ is a positive integer such that $e(g) > h+1$ then, for every $m_1,\ldots,m_h \in I_1$ such that $m_1+\ldots+m_h \in I$, we have $m_1+\ldots+m_h \in I_1$.
nodes.content_preview: Let g G be a semirational element of order n. Let I=m | 1 m n, (m,n)=1, I_1=m I | g g^m, I_2=m I | g^-1 g^m.
nodes.label: i1i2i
nodes.proof: Assume $m_1,\ldots,m_h \in I_1$ satisfy $m_1+\ldots+m_h \in I \setminus I_1$. By assumption $m_1+\ldots+m_h \in I_2$ so $m=-m_1-\ldots-m_h \in I_1$ and $g^{m_1} \cdots g^{m_h} g^m = 1$. Since $m_1,\ldots,m_h,m \in I_1$, this implies $e(g) \leq h+1$, a contradiction.

references.context:
We show that $e(g)=3$. For this we use Lemma \ref{eq} for $k=3$, specifically,  
the fact that $e(g)=3$

nodes.proof:
Let $g=su$. If $u=1$ or $s=1$ then $e(g)\leq 3$.  Suppose that $s\neq 1$ and $u\neq 1$. Then $s$ is not regular. Let $h\in H=\SU_3(q)$ be such that    $g= Z(H)h$. (Note that $|Z(H)|=3.$) One easily observes that the Jordan form of $h$ is 
$\begin{pmatrix}a&1&0\\ 0&a&0\\0 &0&a^{-2}\end{pmatrix}$.  It follows that $h$ lies in a conjugacy class $C_5^{(k)}$ in \cite[Table 2]{Si}, which provides the character table of $G$. 
(See \cite[Table 1.1, p.565]{Ge} for the corrections.) In particular, $|u|=p$,
where $p|q$ is a prime, and $|s|\neq 3$ divides $q+1$. Note that $g,g^{-1}$ are not conjugate so $e(g)>2$. 

  
We show that $e(g)=3$. For this we use Lemma \ref{eq} for $k=3$, specifically,  
the fact that $e(g)=3$ if and only if

$$\sum_{\chi \in \mbox{Irr}(G)} \frac{\chi(g)^3}{\chi(1)}\neq 0.$$

For $\chi \in \mbox{Irr}(G)$ set $A_{\chi}=\{\psi \in \mbox{Irr}(G)\ |\ \psi(1)=\chi(1)\}$. Using the character table of $G$, we observe that the following holds. 

\begin{itemize}
\item If $\chi(1)=q^2-q$ then $|\chi(g)| \leq 1$ and $|A_{\chi}|=1$.
\item If $\chi(1)=q^2-q+1$ then $|\chi(g)| <2$ and $|A_{\chi}| = (q-2)/3$.
\item If $\chi(1)=q^3$ then $\chi(g)=0$.
\item If $\chi(1)=(q+1)^2(q-1)/3$ then $\chi(g)=0$.
\item If $\chi(1)=q(q^2-q+1)$ then $|\chi(g)|=1$ and $|A_{\chi}|=(q-2)/3$.
\item If $\chi(1)=q^3+1$ then $|\chi(g)|=1$ and $|A_{\chi}|=(q^2-q-2)/6$
see \cite[Table 2]{Si}. 
\item If $\chi(1)=(q-1)(q^2-q+1)/3$ then $|\chi(g)|=1$ and $|A_{\chi}|=3$.
\item If $\chi(1)=(q-1)(q^2-q+1)$ then $|\chi(g)| \leq 3$ and $|A_{\chi}| \leq (q-2)(q+1)/6$. This is the number of pairs $(u,v)$ with $1\leq u\leq (q+1)/3$ and $u<v<2(q+1)/3$ \cite[Table 3.1]{Ge}. 
\end{itemize}
In the above discussion, all the possible irreducible character degrees were mentioned. Therefore 
\begin{align*}
\left| \sum_{1 \neq \chi \in \mbox{Irr}(G)} \frac{\chi(g)^3}{\chi(1)} \right| \leq & \frac{1}{q^2-q} + \frac{8(q-2)}{3(q^2-q+1)} + \frac{(q-2)}{3q(q^2-q+1)} + \frac{q^2-q-2}{6(q^3+1)} \\
& + \frac{9}{(q-1)(q^2-q+1)} + \frac{27(q-2)(q+1)}{6(q-1)(q^2-q+1)}.
\end{align*}

This is strictly less than $1$ if $q \geq 8$. The case $q=5$ can be checked by \cite{gap}.

nodes.content: \label{rr2} Let $G=\PGL_2(q)$ or $\PU_2(q)$. Then every semisimple element of $G$ is real.
nodes.content_preview: Let G=_2(q) or _2(q). Then every semisimple element of G is real.
nodes.label: rr2
nodes.proof:
Note that the groups $\PGL_2(q)$ and $\PU_2(q)$ are isomorphic (see \cite[Lemma 4.9]{DZ8}). So it suffices to deal with $\PGL_2(q)$. Let $H=\GL_2(q)$ and let $g\in H$. Let $V$ be the underlying space for $H$. Suppose first that $g$ is reducible on $V$. Then, under some basis of $V$, we can express $g=\diag(a,b)$. 
Then  $g'=\diag(b,a)$ is conjugate to $g$  and $gg'$ is scalar. Whence the result in this case.
 
Suppose that $g$ is irreducible.  Then the centralizer of $g$ in ${\rm Mat}_2(q)$ is a field
by Schur's lemma,  which is isomorphic to $\mathbb{F}_{q^2}$. The nontrivial Galois automorphism $\gamma$ of $\mathbb{F}_{q^2}/\mathbb{F}_q$ sends $x\in \mathbb{F}_{q^2}$ to $x^q$. By the Skolem-Noether theorem, $\gamma$ is realized via an inner 
automorphism of $\GL_2(q)$, and hence $g^q = hgh^{-1}$ for some   $h \in \GL_2(q)$.
Then $gg^q\in \mathbb{F}_q$ is scalar in $\GL_2(q)$. So again $g$ is real in $\PGL_2(q)$.

The result for $\PSU_4(3)$ and $\PSU_4(3)$ follows by \cite{gap}. Now we prove the first part. By Lemma \ref{un2},  $e(g)\leq 4$ if $g\in G$ is semisimple, and $e(g)\leq 3$ if $g$ is unipotent (Lemma  \ref{u26}).   
 Let $H=\SU_4(q)=\SU(V)$, let $h\in H$ be such that $g=hZ(H)$ and $h=su$,
where $s\neq 1$ is semisimple, $u\neq 1$ is unipotent and $su=us $. Let $C$ be the conjugacy class of $h$ in $H$.

  Let $J$ be the Jordan form of $u$ in $\GL_4(q^2)$. Then $J\in\{J_4,\diag(J_3,1),\diag(J_2,J_2)\}$. In the former case $su=us$ implies $s$ is scalar, so $e(g)\leq 3$. In the following discussion we use Observation \ref{centsem}.

If $J=\diag(J_3,1)$ then $h=\diag(\mu\cdot J_3,\mu^{-3})$.
In the notation of \cite{Si} (see also \cite{Ge, Or}), $J_3\in \PSU_3(q)$ belongs to one of  $d=(3,q+1)$ conjugacy classes 
$C_3^{(0,k)}$, where $0 \leq k < d$ (which glue in $\PU_3(q)$).
So, let $D$ be any of these classes,  and let $D'$ be the conjugacy
class of $C_8^{(1)}$. Then, $D'$ consists of elements of order
$(q^2-q+1)/d$. Using the character table of $\PSU_3(q)$, one concludes that $D'\subset D^2$. So there  exists $x \in \PSU_3(q)$ such that
the product $t:=J_3\cdot xJ_3x^{-1}$ has order $(q^2- q +1)/d$. It follows that $C^2$ 
contains an element $y=\diag(\mu^2t,\mu^{-6})$. As $t$ is irreducible in $\U_3(q)$, $t$ does not  have an eigenvalue in $\mathbb{F}_{q^2}$, and hence $y$ is regular semisimple.  
By Lemma \ref{Gow}, some product of $3$ conjugates of $y$ is scalar. So $e(g)\leq 6$. 

 
Assume now that $J=\diag(J_2,J_2)$. 
Then $W=(\Id-u)V$ is a totally isotropic space of dimension 2. Let $s_1\in \GL_2(q^2)$
be the restriction of $s$ on $W$. Then  the action of $s$ on $V/W$ is $s_2:={}^t\gamma(s^{-1}_1)$, where $\gamma$ is the nontrivial Galois automorphism 
of $\mathbb{F}_{q^2}/\mathbb{F}_{q}$ extended to $\GL_2(q^2)$  (see for instance \cite[Lemma 4.8]{ez1}).
 By Lemma \ref{rr2}, the product of two conjugates of $s_1$ by an element of $\SL_2(q^2)$ is scalar in $\GL_2(q^2)$. So the  product $h_1$, say, of  two conjugates of $h$ by some element of $H$ is a matrix product of a matrix $t:=\diag(\mu \cdot \Id_2,\mu^{-q} \cdot \Id_2)$ and  a unipotent matrix $u'$ of the form   $\begin{pmatrix} \Id_2&A\\ 0& \Id_2\end{pmatrix}$, where $A$ is a $(2\times 2)$-matrix over  $\mathbb{F}_{q^2}$. Moreover,
$t\in \langle h_1\rangle$ and hence $u':=t^{-1}h$ is unipotent and $u't=tu'$. Then either
 $u'=1$ or $t$ is scalar. In the latter case $e(g)\leq 3$. As $\diag(\mu^{-q} \cdot \Id_2,\mu \cdot \Id_2)$ is conjugate to $t$ by a matrix $\begin{pmatrix}0&\Id_2\\ \Id_2&0 \end{pmatrix}$, we have $e(g)\leq 4$.

\label{isomodules}
Let $G = \langle s \rangle$ be a finite cyclic group and let $\phi,\tau$ be two finite dimensional irreducible representations of $G$ over a finite field $F$. If the matrices $\phi(s)$, $\tau(s)$ have an eigenvalue in common, then $\phi$ and $\tau$ are equivalent, i.e. the corresponding $F[G]$-modules are isomorphic.
nodes.content_preview: Let G = s be a finite cyclic group and let , be two finite dimensional irreducible representations of G over a finite field F.
nodes.label: isomodules
nodes.proof:
Let $F_1$ be the field $F(\zeta)$ where $\zeta$ is a primitive $|G|$-root of unity. Then, over $F_1$, $\phi$ is a direct sum of absolutely irreducible constituents that are obtained from each other by Galois conjugations by elements of $\mathcal{G}(F_1/F)$. We can say that they form a Galois group orbit. See \cite[Theorem 19.4(ii)]{Feit}. The same is true for $	au$, so the orbits either coincide or are disjoint.

Note that two absolutely irreducible representations $\mu$, $
u$ of a cyclic group $\langle s angle$ are the same if and only if $\mu(s)=
u(s)$. Since $\phi(s)$, $	au(s)$ have an eigenvalue in common, and this eigenvalue belongs to $F_1$, they share a $1$-dimensional component, so the orbits are the same. It follows that $\phi$ and $	au$ have the same irreducible constituents over $F_1$, so $\phi(s)$, $	au(s)$ have the same list of eigenvalues up to ordering.
So $\phi$ and $	au$ are equivalent over $F_1$. So $	au(s) = g \phi(s) g^{-1}$ for some $g \in \GL_m(F_1)$, where $m = \dim(W_1)$. In terms of matrix entries, the equation $g\phi(s) = 	au(s)g$ can be viewed as a homogeneous system of linear equations with indeterminates $g_{ij}$, $1 \leq i,j \leq m$ and coefficients in $F$. Then this system has a non-zero solution over $F$, so there is a matrix $h$ over $F$ such that $h\phi(s) = 	au(s)h$. Note that $\det(h) 
eq 0$. Indeed, otherwise $hW_1=Y
eq W_1$ and hence $	au(s)Y<	au(s) h W_1 = h\phi(s)W_1 < hW_1=Y$, which is false as $	au$ is irreducible.

nodes.content: \label{au8} Let $u$ be a unipotent element in $H=O^\pm _{2d}(q)=O(V)$ with $q$ even, $d$ odd. Then $C_H(u)$ is not a subgroup of $\Omega^\pm _{2d}(q)$.
nodes.content_preview: Let u be a unipotent element in H=O^ _2d(q)=O(V) with q even, d odd. Then C_H(u) is not a subgroup of ^ _2d(q).
nodes.label: au8
nodes.proof:
By \cite[Lemma 4.9]{TZ04}, there exists an orthogonal decomposition $V=V_1 \oplus \ldots \oplus V_f$, such that each $V_i$ is nondegenerate, $uV_i=V_i$ for all $i$ and the Jordan block sizes of $u$ on $V_i$ are the same and distinct on $V_i,V_j$ for $i\neq j$, $i,j\in \{1,\ldots,f\}$. Let $u_i$ be the resriction of $u$ on $V_i$. It suffices to observe that $C_{O(V_i)}(u_i)$ is not contained in $\Omega (V_i)$ for some $i$. As $q$ is even, $\dim V_i$ is even for every $i$  by \cite[Proposition 2.5.1]{KL}, so  $\dim V_i\equiv 2\pmod 4$ for some $i  $. It suffices to show that $C_{O(V_i)}(u_i)$ is not contained in $\Omega (V_i)$. To this end,   Let $a,m$ be such that   the Jordan blocks of $u_i$ consists of $a$ blocks of the same size $m$.
 
If $a$ is odd then then $u_i\notin \Omega (V_i)$ by  \cite[p.182]{C}. Suppose that $a$ is even. Then $m$ is odd and $u_i\in \Omega (V_i)$.  

We use \cite{LiS}. As  $m$ is odd, $u$ is of type $W(m)^{a/2}$ in the notation of \cite[p.117, Theorem 7.3(iii)]{LiS}. In this case $\Omega(V_i)\cong \Omega^+_{am}(q)$ and there is a single conjugacy class of elements of type $W(m)^{a/2}$ in  $\Omega (V_i)$. Therefore, it suffices to observe the following. Let $M$ be a maximal totally singular
subspace of $V_i$; then $V_i = M \oplus M'$, where $M'$  is a maximal totally singular
subspace of $V_i$ too. There is a basis $B$, say, of $V_i$ such that $B\cap M$,
$B\cap M'$ are bases of $M,M'$, respectively, and the Gram matrix of $B$ is 
$\begin{pmatrix}0&\Id_k\\ \Id_k&0\end{pmatrix}$
with $k=\dim M$. Let $u_i'=\diag(A,{}^t A^{-1})$, where $A\in \GL(M)$ is such that the Jordan forms of $u_i,u_i'$ coincide. Then $u_i'\in \Omega(V_i)$ is of type  $W(m)^{a/2}$. As there is a single conjugacy class of elements of this type in $\Omega(V_i)$, we can assume that $u_i=u'_i$. To show that 
$C_{O(V_i)}(u_i)$ contains an element  in $ O(V_i)\setminus \Omega(V_i)$, observe that 
if  $y=\begin{pmatrix}0&\Id_{k}\\ \Id_{k}&0\end{pmatrix}$
then $yu_iy^{-1}=\diag({}^tA^{-1},A)$. As $A$ and ${}^tA^{-1}$ have the same Jordan form, we have $xAx^{-1}={}^tA^{-1}$ for some $x\in \GL_{ k}(q)$, and $zyu_iy^{-1}z^{-1}=u_i $ for $z=\diag(x,{}^tx^{-1})\in \Omega(V_i)$. Note that $y$ is the product of $k$ reflections. As the spinor norm of a reflection is not equal to 1, so is the spinor norm of $y$ as $k$ is odd.

nodes.content: \label{qe1} Let $F$ be an algebraically closed field and let  $A,B\in \GL_n(F)=\GL(V)$ be diagonalizable elements with exactly two eigenvalues. Let $X=\langle A,B\rangle$. Then the composition factors of X on V are of dimension $1$ or $2$.
nodes.content_preview: Let F be an algebraically closed field and let A,B _n(F)=(V) be diagonalizable elements with exactly two eigenvalues. Let X= A,B.
nodes.label: qe1
nodes.proof:
Suppose the contrary, and let $W$ be a composition factor of dimension $d>2$. Since $A$ and $B$ are diagonalizable, they both have exactly two eigenvalues on $W$. So we can assume that $W=V$, so $X$ is irreducible.  

Let $\lambda_1,\lambda_2$,  $\mu_1,\mu_2$ be the eigenvalues   of $A,B$, respectively, and we can assume  (by reordering them)  that 
the multiplicity of $\lambda_1$  and of $\mu_1$ is at least $n/2$.    Let $V_1,V_2$ be 
$\lambda_1,\mu_1$-eigenspaces of $A,B$, respectively. As $X$ is irreducible, we have $V_1\cap V_2=0$, and hence $\dim V_1=\dim V_2=n/2$ and $V_1+V_2=V$. Choose a basis $K$
of $V$ such that $K_i:=K\cap V_i$ is a basis of $V_i$, $i=1,2$, ordered so that the elements of $K_1$ are prior to those of $K_2$. Under such a basis the matrices of $A,B$ are of the form
$$\begin{pmatrix}\lambda_1 \cdot \Id&C\\ 0&\lambda_2 \cdot \Id\end{pmatrix}, \hspace{1cm}
\begin{pmatrix}\mu_2 \cdot \Id&0\\ D&\mu_1 \cdot \Id\end{pmatrix}$$ 
where $C,D$ are square matrices of size $n/2$, and $D\neq 0$ as $X$ is irreducible.
Let $\eta:V_1\rightarrow  V_2$ be the mapping defined by $\eta(v) := (B-\mu_2\Id)v\,$ 
for $v\in V_1$.
Since ${\rm ker}\, \eta$ is $X$-stable, $D$ is nonsingular, so $\eta(B_1)$ is a basis of $V_2$, hence we can choose $K_2=\eta(K_1)$ so that $D$ is replaced by the identity matrix.  
Now we can take $C$ to the upper triangular form  by
conjugating both $A,B$ by a suitable matrix $N=\diag(M,M)$ with $M\in \GL_{n/2}(F)$. Note that $NBN^{-1}=B$. Then the vectors $v_1=(1,0,\ldots, 0)$, $v_2=(0,\ldots, 0,1,0,\ldots ,0)\in F^{2n}$ span a 2-dimensional $X$-stable subspace of $V$ (here $1$ is located at the $(n+1)$-th position).

if and only if $V$ is of type $+$ and   $4|(q-1)$

\label{lemmaPSL}
Let $n \geq 2$ be an integer, $F$ a field, $H=\SL_n(F)$, $G=\PSL_n(F)$. Let $\mu \in F^{\times}$ and let $g=\diag(\mu^{1-n},\mu,\ldots,\mu) \in H$. Let $l \in \{1,\ldots,n-1\}$ be such that $g^{x_1} \ldots g^{x_l} = \lambda \cdot I \in H$ for some $x_1,\ldots,x_l \in \GL_n(F)$, $\lambda \in F$. Then $\mu^{ln}=1$. In particular, if $F$ is finite of size $q$ and $d=(n,q-1)$, if $e(G) < n$ then $e(G) \geq (q-1)/d$.
nodes.content_preview: Let n 2 be an integer, F a field, H=_n(F), G=_n(F). Let F^ and let g=(^1-n,,,) H. Let l 1,,n-1 be such that g^x_1 g^x_l = I H for some x_1,,x_l...
nodes.label: lemmaPSL
nodes.proof: The last claim follows by choosing $\mu$ of multiplicative order $q-1$, since then $\mu^{ln}=1$ implies that $q-1$ divides $ln$, so $(q-1)/d$ divides $l$. Now we prove the first claim, i.e. that $\mu^{ln}=1$. If $\mu^n=1$ the claim is trivial. Now assume that $\mu^n \neq 1$. Then $\mu^{1-n} \neq \mu$ so the matrix $g$ is not scalar. In particular, the $g$-eigenspace of $\mu$ has dimension $n-1$. Assume $g^{x_1} \ldots g^{x_l} = \lambda \cdot \Id \in H$ where each $x_i \in H$. Let $W_i=\{v \in V\ |\ g^{x_i}(v)=\mu v\}$ be the $g^{x_i}$-eigenspace of $\mu$ and let $U$ be the $g$-eigenspace of $\mu$, then we have an isomorphism $U \to W_i$ defined by $u \mapsto x_i^{-1}(u)$. Therefore $\dim(W_i)=n-1$ for all $i=1,\ldots,l$. Set $W:=\bigcap_{i=1}^l W_i$. Then $\dim(W) \geq n-l > 0$. Moreover $g^{x_1} \ldots g^{x_l}$ acts as the multiplication by $\mu^l$ on $W$, so $\mu^l=\lambda$ and hence $\mu^{ln} = \lambda^n=\det(\lambda\cdot \Id)=1$.

nodes.proof:
Observe that $e(\GL_n(2))=3$ for $n=3,4$ as $\GL_3(2)\cong \PSL_2(7)$ and $\GL_4(2)=A_8$. Let $n=5$.

Let $g\in G$ and let $g=su$, where $s\in \langle g\rangle$  is of odd order, $u$ is a 2-power.   If 
$s=1$ then $e(u)=2$. Suppose that $s\neq 1 $. In view of Lemma \ref{Gow} we can assume that $s$ is not regular. Then $s$ is reducible by Schur's lemma. Let $V_1,\ldots,V_k$ be the homogeneous components of $s$ on $V$, and we can assume that $\dim V_1\geq \dim V_2\geq \ldots \geq \dim V_k$. If $\dim V_k=1$ then $g\in \diag(\GL_4(2),1)$ and the result follows since we know that $e(\GL_4(2))=3$. So we  assume that $\dim V_k\geq 2$, and hence $k=2$, $\dim V_1=3$, $\dim V_2=2 $. Note that the homogeneous components of $s$ are $g$-stable. So $gV_i=V_i$ for $i=1,2$. 
Then $g\in  X_1,X_2$, $X_1\cong  \GL_3(2)$, $X_2\cong \GL_2(2)$. We can write  $g=\diag(g_1,g_2)$, and let $g_i=s_iu_i$ for $i=1,2$. Then $s_i$ is either irreducible on $V_i$ or $s_i=\Id$. If both $s_1,s_2$ are irreducible then $s$ is regular by \cite{at}.
So $s\neq 1,u\neq 1$, and either $g_1=s_1$, $g_2=u_2$ or  $g_1=u_1$, $g_2=s_2$.
In the latter case each $u_1$, $s_2$ is real, so $g$ is real. In the former case $|s_1|=7$, $|u_2|=2$, so $|g|=14$.

For this $g$ we can use the character table \cite[Page 70]{at}. Note that the 4 characters 
of degrees 496 take value $b_7,\overline{b_7},-b_7,-\overline{b_7}$ so their cubes sum to 0.  We have
$$\sum_{\chi\in{\rm Irr}(G)}\frac{\chi(g)^3}{\chi(1)}=1+\frac{-1}{155}+ \frac{1}{930}+\frac{1}{960} + \frac{-1}{1240}>0.$$
This proves the claim.

Let $g=su$ with $s$ semisimple and $u$ unipotent. In the notation of Lemma \ref{in3}, $s\in M_1$, $u\in M_2$, and $s$ is irreducible in $M_1\cong \GL_k(3)$.  Let $M_3\subset M_1$, $M_4\subset M_2$ be subgroups isomorphic to $\SL_k(3), \SL_l(3)$, respectively. Since the ground field has $3$ elements, $ \langle s,M_3 \rangle$ is either $M_1$ or $M_3$. 
By Corollary \ref{GuT}, a product of $3$ conjugates of $s$ in $\langle s,M_3\rangle$ is scalar and the conjugation elements can be chosen in $M_3$. In addition, if $u$ is not real then a product of 3 conjugates of $u$ in $M_2$ equals 1 by Lemma \ref{u26}. If $u$ is real 
then  $u$ is rational in $M_4$  by \cite[Lemma 2.2(ii)]{TZ05}. 
 Then $u$ is conjugate to $u^{-2}$,  so some product of $3$ conjugates of $u$ in $M_2$ equals 1. It follows that a product of $3$ conjugates of $g$ is scalar and the conjugation elements can be taken in $\SL_n(3)$.

nodes.proof:
Suppose that $h \in G$ is semisimple. Let $V=\bigoplus_{i=1}^k V_i$ be a decomposition of $V$ as a direct sum of minimal $\langle h \rangle$-stable subspaces of $V$. Let $h_i$ be the projection of $h$ on $V_i$ for $i=1,\ldots ,k$.  Then $h_i$ is irreducible on $V_i$. Note that $|\GL(V_i) : \SL(V_i) Z(\GL(V_i))| \in\{1,3\}$. By Corollary  \ref{GuT},
there are $x_i,y_i\in \SL(V_i)$ such that $h_ix_ih_ix_i^{-1}y_ih_iy_i^{-1}\in Z(\GL(V_i))$.
This is also true for  $i$ with $\dim V_i= 1$.
It follows that the product of some 3 conjugates of $h$ in $H$ acts scalarly on each $V_i$. 
Since $q=4$, we have  $e(h)\leq 9$.

In general, let $h=su$, where $1\neq s\in H$ is semisimple, $1\neq u\in H$ is unipotent and $us=su$. Then $e_{C_G(s)}(u)\leq 2$. Indeed, $C_{\GL(V)}(s)$ is a direct product of groups isomorphic to $\GL_{m}(q^k)$ for various $m,k$, see \cite[Lemma 3.2]{TZ04}. Therefore, $u$ is contained in a subgroup of $C_{\GL(V)}(s)\cap H$ isomorphic to a direct product of groups $\SL_{m}(q^k)$, since $|u|$ is a $p$-element for $p|q$ and $|GL_{m}(q^k)/\SL_{m}(q^k)|$ is a $p'$-group. By \cite[Theorem 1.7]{TZ04}, $u$ is real in $C_G(s)$. Therefore, $s^2$ is a product of 2 conjugates of $h$; as $e(s^2)\leq 9$, we have $e(h)\leq 18$.

nodes.proof:
The second claim follows from \cite{gap}, so we will now prove that $e(G) \leq 5$. Let $g=su \in G$, where $s$ is semisimple, $u$ is unipotent and $su=us$. If $g$ is semisimple then $e(g)\leq 5$
by Lemma \ref{un2}. If $g$ is unipotent then $e(g)\leq 2$ by \cite[Theorem 1.8(ii)]{TZ04}. 

Suppose that  $g$ is neither semisimple nor unipotent.   Let $h\in H=\SL_5(3)$ be such that $g=hZ(H)$, and $h=su$, where $s,u\in  \langle h\rangle$, $s$ is is semisimple, $u$ is unipotent. Then $s$ is not scalar. Recall that an $(n \times n)$-matrix $A$ over a field $F$ is called cyclic if there exists $x \in F^n$ such that $\{x,Ax,\ldots,A^{n-1}x\}$ is a basis of $F^n$. The matrix $A$ is cyclic if and only if its Jordan canonical form contains only one Jordan block for every eigenvalue.

We   use Observation \ref{centsem} and the notation therein in the following discussion, in which we list the possibilities for $u$ (up to conjugation). In particular, $n_1,\ldots ,n_k$ are the dimensions of the homogeneous components of $s$.

We denote by $J_m$ the canonical Jordan block of size $m$. If $x$ is a $p$-element in $\GL_n(q)$, where $p$ is the prime dividing $q$, then $(x-1)^n=0$, therefore if $\GL_n(q)$ contains a unipotent element whose Jordan form is $J_m$, then $n \geq m$. Since $s$ is not scalar, $k \geq 2$.
 
(a) $u=\diag(J_4,1)$. The fact that $u \in C_G(s)$ implies that $k=2$ and $n_1/m_1 \geq 4$, so $m_1=m_2=1$, $n_1=4$, $n_2=1$. Therefore $h$ is a cyclic matrix whose all eigenvalues are in $\mathbb{F}_3$. By \cite[Theorem 3]{Lev94}, $g^{-1}$ is the product of two conjugates of $h$, whence $e(g)\leq 3$.

(b) $u=\diag(J_3,J_2)$. In this case $n_1=3$, $m_1=1$, $n_2=2$, $m_2=1$, $s=\diag(s_1,s_2)$,   $s_i=\mu_i \cdot \Id$ for $i=1,2$, $\mu_i\in \mathbb{F}_3$ and $\mu_1^3\mu_2^2=1$. As $s_1\neq s_2$, $h$ is a cyclic matrix. So again $e(g)\leq 3$ by \cite[Theorem 3]{Lev94}.
 

(c) $u=\diag(J_3,1,1)$. In this case $k \in \{2,3\}$, $n_1=3$, $m_1=1$, $s=\diag(\pm  \Id_3,s_2)$, $s_2\in \GL_2(3)$. 
Then $J_3$ is real in $\SL_3(3)$ and $s_2$ is real in $\PGL_2(3)$. Using $-\Id_3$, if necessary, to adjust the determinant, we deduce that the product of some two conjugates of $g$ in $G$ is $\diag( \Id_3,\nu \cdot \Id_2)$, where  $\nu=\pm 1$. Then  $e(g)\leq 4$.

(d) $u=\diag(J_2,1,1,1)$. In this case $k \in \{2,3,4\}$, $n_1=2$, $m_1=1$, $s=\diag(\mu \cdot \Id_2,s_2)$, $\mu=\pm 1$, $s_2\in \SL_3(3)$.
 If $s_2$ is regular, then the product of  3 conjugates of $s_2$ in $\SL_3(3)$ equals $ \Id_3$ by Lemma \ref{Gow}, as $\det (-\Id_3)=-1$. If $\mu=-1$ then, by Lemma \ref{s33}, the product of 3 conjugates of $J_2$ in $\SL_2(3)$ equals $-\Id$, so the product of some $3$ conjugates of $-J_2$ in  $\SL_2(3)$ equals 1. Then  $e(g)\leq 3$.  If $\mu=1$ then, since
$J_2^3=1$, again $e(g)\leq 3$. If $s_2$ is not regular in $\SL_3(3)$ then $s_2$ centralizes some unipotent element in $\SL_3(3)$, and hence it is diagonalizable with at least two equal eigenvalues which belong to $\mathbb{F}_3$. So we can assume that $s_2=\diag(1,\pm \Id_2)$. Then $g = \diag(\mu.J_1,1,\pm \Id_2)$ is contained in the group $X= \left\{ \diag(A,\det A^{-1},\pm\Id_2)\ |\ A \in \GL_2(3) \right\}$. It follows that $g$ is real in $X$, so $e(g)=2$.
 
(e) $u=\diag(J_2,J_2,1)$. Then $n_1/m_1 \geq 2$. If $m_1 \geq 2$, then $m_1=2$ and $n_1=4$, while if $m_1=1$ then $n_1 \geq 2$. This implies that 
there are two isomorphic irreducible components, and their dimension is $1$ or $2$.
Suppose first that these are of dimension $2$. Then, replacing $g$ by some conjugate, we can assume that $s=\diag(s_1,s_1,t)$, where $s_1\in \GL_2(3)$ is irreducible, $t\in \mathbb{F}_3$. 
Then $t=1$ as $ \det s_1^2=1$. So $s=\diag(s_1,s_1,1)$. We deduce that $h=\diag(A,1)$, where $A=s_2\otimes J_2 \in \GL_2(3)\otimes \GL_2(3)$. Note that $\GL_2(3)\otimes \GL_2(3)\subset \SL_4(3)$.  
Since $J_2$ is real in $\GL_2(3)$, and semisimple elements are real in  $\GL_2(3)$ too, the result follows. Suppose now that $s$ has at least $2$ isomorphic components of dimension $1$. Then some eigenvalue $\mu$ of $h$ is of multiplicity at least 2. Let $W$ be the $\mu$-eigenspace of $h$. If $\dim W=2$ or $3$ then $h=\diag(-J_2,J_2,1)$ 
and  $e(h)=2$ as $J_2$ is real in $\GL_2(3)$. If $\dim W=4 $ then  $h=\diag(-J_2,-J_2,1)$, and again  $e(h)=2$.

nodes.proof:
Let $V$ be the underlying space for $H$. By \cite[Satz 2]{Huppert}, $V=\bigoplus_i V_i$, where $V_i$'s are minimal $\langle s \rangle$-stable non-degenerate subspaces of $V$. Let $s_i$ be the restriction of $s$ to $V_i$. Then either $s_i$ is irreducible, or $V_i=W_i \oplus W_i'$,
where $W_i,W_i'$ are totally isotropic minimal $\langle s_i \rangle$-stable subspaces. In addition, there exists a basis of $V_i$ such that if $M_i$ is the matrix of $s_i$ on $W_i$ then 
the matrix $M_i'$ of $s_i$ on $W_i'$ is ${}^t\gamma(M_i)^{-1}$, where $\gamma$ is a non-trivial Galois automorphism of ${\mathbb F}_4$ (\cite[Satz 2]{Huppert}). 
As $W_i$ is irreducible, $s_i$ is a regular element of $\GL(W_i)$. Moreover, by Schur's lemma $s_i$ is regular in $\GL(V_i)$ unless $W_i,W_i'$ are isomorphic $\mathbb{F}_{q^2}\langle s_i\rangle $-modules, equivalently, $M_i$ and $M'_i$ are similar as matrices of $\GL_d(q^2)$, $d=\dim W_i$. Then $M_i$ is contained in a subgroup $X_i$ of  $\GL_d(q^2)$ isomorphic to $\U_d(q)$. It follows that $V_i$ is a direct sum of  two $\langle s_i \rangle$-stable non-degenerate subspaces. Therefore, if we choose the decomposition $V=\bigoplus_i V_i$ with maximal number of non-degenerate terms $V_i$ then $s_i$ is a regular element in $\GL(V_i)$ and $\U(V_i)$.

Since $|\U(V_i)/Z(\U(V_i)) \SU(V_i)|\in\{1,3\}$, by Corollary \ref{GuT} there are $x_i,y_i\in \SU(V_i)$ such that $s_i x_i s_i x_i^{-1} y_i s_i y_i^{-1} \in Z(\U(V_i))$. Therefore, the product of some 3 conjugates of $s$ is of order 3 or 1.  This implies $e(s)\leq 9$. 

Let $h\in H$ and 
$h=su$, $s,u\in \langle h\rangle$ with $s$ semisimple, $u$ unipotent. 
Note that $C_{\U(V)}(s)$ is a direct product of groups
isomorphic to $\GL_{m}(q^{2k})$ and $\U_m(q^k)$ for various $m,k$, see \cite[Lemma 3.3]{TZ04}. Therefore, $u$ is contained in a subgroup of $C_{\GL(V)}(s)\cap H$ isomorphic to a direct product of groups  $\SL_{m}(q^k)$ and  $\SU_m(q^k)$. By \cite[Theorem 1.7(ii)]{TZ04}, applied to every multiple, $u$ is real in $C_G(s)$. Therefore, $s^2$ is a product of 2 conjugates of $h$; as $e(s^2)\leq 9$, we have $e(h)\leq 18$.

Let $G=G_2(q)$, q even.  Then $e(G)\leq 4$.
nodes.content_preview: Let G=G_2(q), q even. Then e(G) 4.

nodes.proof:
The character table of $G$ is available in \cite{EY}. By inspection of this  one observes that the irreducible character values are not real only at two conjugacy classes, denoted by  $B_2(1)$ and $ B_2(2)$. So $e(g)=2$ unless 
$g\in B_2(1)\cup B_2(2)$.  

Representatives of  $B_i(1)$, $i=1,2,
$ are written in \cite[Table IV-1]{EY} and in \cite{Enomoto} as
$h(\omega,\omega,\omega)y_i$, where $y_i$ are unipotent,   $h:=h(\omega,\omega,\omega)^3=1$ and $hy_i=y_ih$, see \cite[p.327]{EY}.  So $|g|$ is even and hence $g,g^2$ are not conjugate. Therefore, $g^2$ is real, and hence $e(g)\leq 4$.

\label{e88}  Let $\mathbf{G}$ be the simple algebraic group of type $ E_8$ in characteristic $p>0$ and let $1\neq s\in  \mathbf{G}$  be a semisimple element. 
 \smallskip


$(1)$ The group $\mathbf{C}:=C_{\mathbf{G}}(s)$ is connected reductive, $\mathbf{C}=Z(\mathbf{C})\cdot \mathbf{G}_1\cdots \mathbf{G}_m$ for some simple algebraic groups
$\mathbf{G}_1\,\ldots ,\mathbf{G}_m;$

\smallskip
$(2)$ the groups $\mathbf{G}_i$, $1\leq i\leq m$, are either of exceptional type distinct from $E_8$, or of classical groups of rank at most $8$.
nodes.content_preview: Let be the simple algebraic group of type E_8 in characteristic p>0 and let 1 s be a semisimple element. (1) The group :=C_(s) is connected...
nodes.label: e88
nodes.proof:
(1) $\mathbf{C}$ is reductive (that is, it contains no non-trivial unipotent normal subgroups), see \cite[3.9 on p. 197]{Sbo}, and connected  by \cite[Theorem 14.16(i) or 14.20]{MTe}, since the simple algebraic group of type $ E_8$ is simply connected. So the claim is a well known fact of general theory of algebraic groups, see for instance \cite[\S 1.8, pp.16-17]{C}.
 
(2) A maximal torus of $\mathbf{C}$ is the product of some maximal tori of the multiples $Z(\mathbf{C})$, $\mathbf{G}_1$, $\ldots$, $\mathbf{G}_m$, and the center of a simple algebraic group is a finite group. Therefore, the rank of $\mathbf{C}$ equals the sum of the ranks
of the multiples, and hence the rank of every group $\mathbf{G}_i$ is at most $8$. 
This implies the claim for classical groups. If some $\mathbf{G}_i$ is of type $E_8$
then $m=1$ and the rank of 
$ Z(\mathbf{C})$ equals $0$; therefore, this group is finite. As $\mathbf{G}$ is connected,  $ Z(\mathbf{C})$ is contained in 
$\mathbf{G}_1$, so $\mathbf{C}$ is a simple algebraic group of type $E_8$. 
It is well known that in this case $Z(\mathbf{C})=1$, hence $s=1$, a contradiction.

nodes.proof:
If $p=2,3,5,7 $ then $e(G)\leq 16,27,25,47$ by Lemma \ref{e62}. Let $p>2$.

  If $g\in C$ is regular semisimple then, by Lemma \ref{Gow}, $C^2$
contains  every semisimple element $x\neq 1$ of $G$ (when $G$ is simple.)
As  $B$ contains a non-trivial semisimple element for $q>2$,  the result follows in this case.
 
Suppose that $g=s$ is not regular semisimple.   Then $s\in K$, where $K$ is a cyclic group
with $O_p(K)\neq 1$. By a Borel-Tits theorem  \cite[Theorem 13.1]{GL},  $K$ is contained in a proper parabolic subgroup $P$ of $G$, and $O_p(K)\subseteq O_p(P)$. In addition, $s\in L\cong P/O_p(P)$, where $L$ is a Levi subgroup of $P$.   Recall that  $P=LO_p(P)$, with   $ L\cap O_p(P)=1$.

We can assume that $G$ is of universal type, that is, $G=\mathbf{G}^\si$,
where $\mathbf{G} $ is a simply connected simple group of type $E_6$, and $\si$ is a suitable Frobenius endomorphism of $\mathbf{G} $.  
Then   there exists a reductive connected subgroup $\mathbf{L}$ of $\mathbf{G} $ such that  $L=\mathbf{L}^\si$ \cite[Proposition 26.1]{MTe}. 
 By \cite[Proposition 13.14]{MTe}, $\mathbf{L}'$ is simply connected. Let $m=|Z(L_u)|$. It is well known that $(m,q)=1$. By Lemma \ref{gf3}, $x^m\in L_u.Z(L)$  for every $x\in L$. In particular, $(g')^m\in Z(L)L_u$  is semisimple. 
 Therefore, $(g')^{md}\in Z(L)$, where $d=\max e(y)$ for $y\in L_u/Z(L_u)$ semisimple. 

Note that $Z(L)$ normalizes every Sylow $p$-subgroup of $L$ and $O_p(P)$, hence every Sylow $p$-subgroup of $P$ and  some   Sylow $p$-subgroup of $G$. As   a Borel subgroup of $G$   is the normalizer of a Sylow $p$-subgroup of $G$,
we conclude that $Z(L)\subset B$. So we have to obtain an upper bound for $md$.

The structure of subgroups $L_u$ can be easily read off from \cite[Tables 9,10]{C23}.   (In those tables  the group under consideration is $G/Z(G)$, but this does not affect the structure of $L_u/Z(L_u)$.)  Note that $E_6(q)$ has 6  maximal parabolic subgroups, ${}^2E_6(q)$ has 4 maximal parabolic subgroups; these are easily detected in the tables by the property $O_p(P)\neq 1$. 

By \cite[Table 9]{C23}, if $G=E_6(q)$ then $L_u/Z(L_u)\in\{ P\Omega_{10}^+(q),\PSL_6(q), \PSL_5(q)\times \PSL_2(q),
 P\Omega_8^+(q)$, $\PSL_3(q)\circ \PSL_3(q)\times \PSL_2(q),\PSL_2(q)\times \PSL_2(q)\times \PSL_3(q)\}$. As $\mathbf{L}'$ is simply connected, we have $m=|Z(L_u)|$ divides $ 4,6,10,4,18,12$, respectively. (This is well known; to be precise $m$ is the $p'$-part of the above number.)  In FACT, $4,6,10,4,6,6$, respectively, TO BE PROVEN) As $(g')^m$ is semisimple,  
$d\leq 4,6,10$ for the first 3 groups. We observe that $d=3$ for two last groups.
 
Consider the case where  $L_u/Z(L_u)\cong X_1\times X_2\times X_3$, with all multiples non-trivial. Suppose first that $X_1\cong X_2 \cong \PSL_3(q)$, $X_3\cong \PSL_2(q)$. 
We can write $g'=x_1x_2x_3$, where $x_i\in X_i$, $i=1,2,3$ are semisimple elements. 
If each $x_i$ is a regular element of $X_i$ then $e(g')=3$ by Lemma \ref{Gow}. 
Suppose that some $x_1,x_2$ are regular. Then $x_3=1$, and $e(g')=3$ as above.
Suppose that $x_i$ is not regular for $i\in\{1,2\}$. Let $y_i$ be an element in the pullback of 
$x_i$ in $\SL_3(q)$. Then $y_i$ is not regular, and then $y_i$ is diagonalizable in   $\SL_3(q)$. 
Then the product of 3 conjugates of $y_i$ in $\SL_3(q)$ equals $\Id$, and then a product of 3 conjugates of $x$ in $L_u$ equals 1. 

The case with $X_1\cong \PSL_3(q)$, $X_2\cong X_3 \cong \PSL_2(q)$ is similar.

We conclude that $md$ divides $16,36,100,54,36$, respectively. 
 

Let $G=2E_6(q)$. 
By \cite[Table 10]{C23},  $L_u/Z(L_u)\in\{ P\Omega_{8}^-(q),\PSU_6(q), \PSL_3(q^2)\times \PSL_2(q),  \PSL_3(q) \times \PSL_2(q^2)\}$. 
Then $d=e_{L_u/Z(L_u)}(g')$ divides $2,6,6,6$, resp. Indeed, the claim follows from  by Lemmas \ref{sn2},  \ref{6u6} for the first two groups. For the last two groups  this follows as above. In addition, $m=|Z(L_u)|=4,6,6,6$, resp. We conclude that $m$ divides $8,36,36,36$, respectively.

references.context: t $C_1$ be the conjugacy class of $s^t$. By Lemma \ref{66b},  $C^{tk}$ meets a split maximal torus $T$ of $G$

nodes.proof:
Let $\mathbf{H}$ be
the simply connected simple algebraic group  of type $E_6$ such that $H=\mathbf{H}^\si$ for some Frobenius endomorphism $\si$ of $\mathbf{H}$ and $G=H/Z(H)$. Note that $|Z(H)|=(3,q-1)$, resp., $(3,q+1)$ if $G=E _6(q)$, resp.,  ${}^2E_6(q)$.

Let $p|q$ be a prime. Recall that a split maximal torus $T$ of $G$ is a complement of a Sylow $p$-subgroup of $G$ in its normalizer (called a Borel subgroup of $G$), see \cite[Cor 24.11]{MTe}.  It is well known that $|T|=(q-1)^6 $
if $H=E_6(q)$ and $|T|=(q^2-1)^2(q-1)^2=(q-1)^4(q+1^2) $ if $H=2E_6(q)$. 
 
Observe that $G$  contains a (maximal) subgroup   of $G$ described in 
\cite[Tables 9,10]{C23} as   $2.(\PSL_2(q)\times \PSL_6(q)).2 $, resp., $2.(\PSL_2(q)\times \PSU_6(q)).2 $; as $q$ is odd, the term $(2,q-1)=2$ in \cite[Tables 9,10]{C23}. 
We denote by $X$ the preimage of this group in $H$.

It follows from the comment of the first paragraph in Section 7 of \cite{C23},
$X=\mathbf{X}^\si$ for some maximal positive-dimensional algebraic subgroup  of $\mathbf{H}$. Clearly, the connected component $\mathbf{X}^\circ$ of $\mathbf{X}$ is of type $A_1\times A_5$. In fact,    $\mathbf{X}^\circ=\mathbf{X}$, see \cite[Table A, p.302]{LSS}. By dimension reason, the maximal tori of $\mathbf{X}$ are maximal tori of   $\mathbf{H}$, and hence ${\mathbf T}_1^\si$ is a maximal torus of $H$ for every $\si$-stable maximal torus   $\mathbf{T}_1$ of $\mathbf{X}$. 
One observes that $X$ contains a subgroup $T_1$ of order $|T|$. 

We claim that $T_1$
is a split maximal torus of $H$. Indeed, the orders of maximal tori of $H=E_6(q)$  
  are listed in \cite[Table II, p.897]{DF}, and there is a unique maximal torus (up to conjugation in $H$) of order $(q-1)^6$, whence the claim in this case.  As stated at the 
end of \cite[p. 903]{DF}, the orders of maximal tori of $2E_6(q)$ are obtained from the orders of those of $E_6(q)$ by replacing $q$ by $-q$ in the 
formulas of the orders   (and taking the absolute value if the result is a negative number). So maximal tori  of order $(q^2-1)^2(q-1)^2$ correspond to those   of order $(q^2-1)^2(q+1)^2$ in $E_6(q)$ (this is denoted by $T_8$ in \cite[Table II, p.897]{DF}). By inspection, one concludes that there is a single maximal torus of this order in $E_6(q)$ and hence a single maximal torus of  order $(q^2-1)^2(q+1)^2$ in ${}^2E_6(q)$.
It follows that $T_1$ and $T$ are conjugate, and hence $T_1$ is  split.

 

Let $x\in T$ and let $D$ be a conjugacy class of $x$. We show that $e(x)\leq 12$, resp., 24. 
We can assume that $x\in T_1\subset H$. Let $Y$ be the subgroup of $H$ generated by unipotent elements. Then $x^2\in Y$ and $Y/Z(Y)= \PSL_2(q)\times  \PSL_6(q)$, resp.,  $\PSL_2(q)\times  \PSU_6(q)$. Set $Y_1= \SL_2(q)\times  \SL_6(q)$, resp.,  $\SL_2(q)\times  \SU_6(q)$, and let $y_1\in Y_1$ be an element in the preimage of $x^2$ in $Y_1$.
Then $y_1=ab$, where $a\in \SL_2(q), $ $b\in \SL_6(q)$, resp.,  $b\in  \SU_6(q)$.

If $G=E_6(q)$ then  the product of some 6 conjugates of $b$ in $\SL_6(q)$ equals 1, and hence the product of some 6 conjugates of $y_1$ in $Y_1$ equals 1 (as the semisimple elements of $\SL_2(q)$ are real). As $Y=Y_1/Z(H)$, we conclude that $e(x)\leq 12$.

Let  $G={}^2E_6(q)$. Then $b$ is contained in a split maximal torus of $\SU_6(q)=\SL(V)$ as well as of $U_6(q)$. This can be describes as follows. Choose a basis of $V$
whose Gram matrix is $\begin{pmatrix}0&\Id_3\\ \Id_3&0\end{pmatrix}$.
Then matrices $\diag(\mu_1,\mu_2,\mu_3,\mu^{-q}_1,\mu^{-q}_2,\mu^{-q}_3)\in U_6(q)$ for $\mu_1,\mu_2,\mu_3\in \mathbb{F}_{q^2}$ form a split maximal  torus of $U_6(q)$, and those of determinant 1 forms a split   split torus of $\SU_6(q)$. Then the product of 3 conjugates of 
$b$ yields a matrix $\diag(\mu.\Id_3,\mu^{-q}.\Id_3)$ for $\mu=\mu_1\mu_2\mu_3$.
Then this matrix is conjugate to $\diag(\mu^{-q}.\Id_3,\mu.\Id_3)$, and the product of these two matrices is scalar $\mu\mu^{-q}.\Id_6$. Therefore, the product of some 6 conjugates of $y_1$ lies in $Z(Y_1)$. Then  the product of some 6 conjugates of
$x^2$ lies in $Z(Y)$, which is of order 2. Therefore, $e(x)\leq 24$.  
  
Let $g\in C$, and  $g=su$, where $s$ is semisimple, $u$ is unipotent elements of $\langle g\rangle$.   By \cite[Theorem 1.5]{TZ04}, the generators of $\langle u \rangle$ lie in at most two conjugacy classes of $C_G(s)$; so $s^t\in C^t$ for $t\leq 3$ and $s^t$ is semisimple. Let $C_1$ be the conjugacy class of $s^t$. By Lemma \ref{66b},  $C^{tk}$ meets a split maximal torus $T$ of $G$, where $k=100,36$
for  $G=E_6(q)$, ${}^2E_6(q)$, resp. It follows that $e(g)\leq 300.12=3600, 108.24=2592 $, resp.
